data.title: Cultural Objects Archives
data.meta_description: The “umbrella” category for all items in the collection, except Oral History Interviews.
data.text:
“Good Morning 1907” Crazy Quilt

This quilt left Floyd County in 1922 when its owner Zora Weeks Slusher moved to North Dakota.

“May 7th 1897” Crazy Quilt

Crazy quilt incorporating more than nineteen different embroidery stitches.

“The Mabry Mill Band”

Oral histories of musicians and dancers who entertained visitors to Mabry Mill on the Blue Ridge Parkway.

“Wish We Knew” Quilt

Arlie Harman Tobler was thirteen years old when she completed this bright and complex quilt.

1851 Courthouse Bricks

Bricks used by Henry Dillon in building the second Floyd County courthouse which replaced the original 1832 structure.

1929 Telephone Directory

Beginning in the early 1900s, cooperatives formed to bring telephone service to selected communities in the county.

A-Model Mandolin

Hansel Roberson crafted this mandolin using curly maple for the sides and neck.

Altizer Rope Bed

Bed passed down in the Aaron and Ada Altizer Family.

Applique Tablecloth

Alice Peterman Tise created this summery table covering for use in her home on Oxford Street.

Arminta Catherine Alderman Keith Market Basket

Market basket passed down through the Alderman/Vaughn family.

Aster the Rhino

One of two rhinos Andy Hylton fashioned from the root of a downed tree.

Aunt Etta’s Diamond Quilt

“Charm” quilt created by Nancy Jane Shank using more than two hundred unique feed sack prints.

Ballard Telephone Exchange

Operators working out of their homes connected callers manually in the early years of telephone service.

Beckwith Pump Organ

Tricentennial model parlor organ available through the Sears, Roebuck and Co. catalog.

Bicentennial Quilt

Commemorative quilt completed by Elzada Boothe in 1976.

Black Walnut Rocking Chair

Craftsman style chair built by the Rev. J.M. Tise.

Blacksmith’s Traveler

When blacksmith Shep Alderman needed a tool to measure a wagon wheel for spokes, he carved his own.

Bleeding Hearts Quilt

The unknown maker of this quilt appliqued and embroidered twenty-four blocks of flowers for this quilt.

Boston Commons Quilt

This pattern quilted by a member of Jessie Tise Heafner’s family is also known as “Garden Path.”

Brick Doll Furniture

Two little girls enjoyed this doll furniture carved by their great-uncle Hines Sutphin.

Broken Star Quilt

Rainbow colors forming a dazzling bedcover donated by Jessie Tise Heafner.

Broomstick Lace

Also called “jiffy” lace, this crocheting technique uses a broomstick in addition to a crochet hook.

Buffalo Mountain Postcard

Snowy view of the Upper and Lower Bluffs after the mountain had been logged.
